title: Lambert's cosine law
text:
In <a href="optics">optics</a>, Lambert's cosine law says that the <a href="radiant%20intensity">radiant intensity</a> or <a href="luminous%20intensity">luminous intensity</a> observed from an ideal <a href="diffuse%20reflection">diffusely reflecting</a> surface or ideal diffuse radiator is <a href="directly%20proportional">directly proportional</a> to the <a href="cosine">cosine</a> of the angle "θ" between the direction of the incident light and the <a href="Normal%20%28geometry%29">surface normal; I = I0cos("θ")</a>. The law is also known as the cosine emission law or Lambert's emission law. It is named after <a href="Johann%20Heinrich%20Lambert">Johann Heinrich Lambert</a>, from his "<a href="Photometria">Photometria</a>", published in 1760.
A surface which obeys Lambert's law is said to be "Lambertian", and exhibits <a href="Lambertian%20reflectance">Lambertian reflectance</a>. Such a surface has the same <a href="radiance">radiance</a> when viewed from any angle. This means, for example, that to the human eye it has the same apparent brightness (or <a href="luminance">luminance</a>). It has the same radiance because, although the emitted power from a given area element is reduced by the cosine of the emission angle, the solid angle, subtended by surface visible to the viewer, is reduced by the same very amount. Because the ratio between power and solid angle is constant, radiance (power per unit solid angle per unit projected source area) stays the same.
Lambertian scatterers and radiators.
When an area element is radiating as a result of being illuminated by an external source, the <a href="irradiance">irradiance</a> (energy or photons/time/area) landing on that area element will be proportional to the cosine of the angle between the illuminating source and the normal. A Lambertian scatterer will then scatter this light according to the same cosine law as a Lambertian emitter. This means that although the radiance of the surface depends on the angle from the normal to the illuminating source, it will not depend on the angle from the normal to the observer. For example, if the <a href="moon">moon</a> were a Lambertian scatterer, one would expect to see its scattered brightness appreciably diminish towards the <a href="terminator%20%28solar%29">terminator</a> due to the increased angle at which sunlight hit the surface. The fact that it does not diminish illustrates that the moon is not a Lambertian scatterer, and in fact tends to scatter more light into the <a href="oblique%20angle">oblique angle</a>s than a Lambertian scatterer.
The emission of a Lambertian radiator does not depend on the amount of incident radiation, but rather from radiation originating in the emitting body itself. For example, if the <a href="sun">sun</a> were a Lambertian radiator, one would expect to see a constant brightness across the entire solar disc. The fact that the sun exhibits <a href="limb%20darkening">limb darkening</a> in the visible region illustrates that it is not a Lambertian radiator. A <a href="black%20body">black body</a> is an example of a Lambertian radiator.

Relating peak luminous intensity and luminous flux.
In general, the <a href="luminous%20intensity">luminous intensity</a> of a point on a surface varies by direction; for a Lambertian surface, that distribution is defined by the cosine law, with peak luminous intensity in the normal direction. For Lambertian surfaces, the same factor of formula_10 relates <a href="luminance">luminance</a> to <a href="luminous%20emittance">luminous emittance</a>, <a href="radiant%20intensity">radiant intensity</a> to <a href="radiant%20flux">radiant flux</a>, and <a href="radiance">radiance</a> to <a href="radiant%20emittance">radiant emittance</a>. Radians and steradians are, of course, dimensionless and so "rad" and "sr" are included only for clarity.
Example: A surface with a luminance of say 100 cd/m2 (= 100 nits, typical PC monitor) will, if it is a perfect Lambert emitter, have a luminous emittance of 100π lm/m2. If its area is 0.1 m2 (~19" monitor) then the total light emitted, or luminous flux, would thus be 31.4 lm.
